Whoa. The fact that this all took place in the 70s is crazy to me. This chilling, coming (and falling) of age story is so heart wrenching and wild that I didn‚Äôt even know how to react to the twist (which I feel terrible calling it a twist because this was a ‚Äúreal diary‚Äù not a fiction novel) *which after some research I believe it is a true to life tale but not 100% a real unabridged diary. Either way excellent story.

I am pretty sure I kept ‚ÄúGo Ask Alice‚Äù by Anonymous from my high school library as it still has my high school stamp on the cover‚Ä¶ either that or I accidentally forgot to take it back üò≠üòÇ Regardless, I loved this book as a high schooler and it also scarred me for life ‚Äî have you read this book? Did it resonate with you? I remember it vividly and I have read it countless times. üìñ

This is such a good book.  I read it many years ago, lent it to a friend and then moved so I never got it back.  I often thought about it but couldn't think of the title, but I googled the subject matter and google found it for me.  It's the diary of a young girl introduced to drugs and what happens to her.  #goaskalicebook #whenshestenfeettall

#GoAskAlice

(üéº When she's 10 feet tall)

By #anonymous 

But actually believed to be a piece of anti-drug #propaganda by #BeatriceSparks. Purporting to be the #diary of a teenage girl who develops a drug problem. The giveaway for me was the description of her trying weed for the first time. Literally nobody reacts like that, fgs üòÇ The description of what she does to herself on acid though was truly horrifying and the ending whips the carpet from under you. 

I mostly enjoyed, although the use of exclamation marks got on my tits. "Aww gee whizz I'm going home to see Mom and Pop today! I'm going to bake a cake! Everything's gonna be swell from now on!" (Not actual quote, although if it earns me millions I'm happy to lie and say it was).

Thank you so much Whaley Alice

#goaskalice#goaskalicebook

Well this was a fun time to read. I‚Äôve been obsessed with the lore surrounding this book for years, and originally bought it as a gift for myself after fall semester. We see how well that turned out. Originally thought to be the real diary of a teenage girl, and later discovered to be mostly if not entirely fictional, Go Ask Alice is certainly a ride. The anonymous protagonist is introduced to drugs at a party and throughout the book struggles with hard drugs, sobriety, and a huge assortment of drug addicted youth. It‚Äôs weird, I was aware while reading that everything I was reading was bogus and it was written to inspire fear, but I couldn‚Äôt help but feel bad for the protagonist at times. If you dig old propaganda and like thinking critically, or watch the original Reefer Madness like it‚Äôs a comedy, this one‚Äôs for you.

Havent been active for a while, but also havent read anything in a while. This book kept me on the edge of my seat when I first read it 11 years ago and it still does now. Such an extraordinary read #GoAskAliceBook #bookstagram #writersofinstagram #readersofinstagram

I read this book in high school and thought, ‚ÄúI want to try LSD!‚Äù I know, not the reaction the book was intended for. It‚Äôs funny to read this book as an adult, especially now that weed is legal. I used to rave about this book. It has always been on my favorites list up until now. I still really like the book, but in a different way. The book is written as a teenage girls diary and her journey to becoming a drug addict. When reading this book it is important to remember that it was written in the 70‚Äôs, this girl is 15 years old, times have changed, drugs have changed and people‚Äôs thoughts on drugs have changed. I think the important takeaway on this book is that drugs don‚Äôt discriminate and can ruin anyone‚Äôs lives.

I'm really liking this book but it's sad though. And I wish I could tell this teen from the book, that there's a lot beauty in the world, than she thinks...but I can't and that hurts. I really recommend this if you have a teen or child. It makes you see through their eyes and it reminds you of how hard it can be when you're only fifteen.
